19.92.text: University Challenge. Asking the questions, Jeremy Paxman.

28.00.text: Hello. Oxford plays Cambridge tonight as two institutions

31.84.text: with daunting reputations in this contest

34.16.text: compete for the first of the two quarterfinal victories

37.52.text: they'll need to take a place in the semifinals.

40.48.text: Now the team from Magdalen College, Oxford,

44.48.text: that has taken the title of series champions four times in the past,

48.00.text: a distinction they share only with Manchester University.

51.68.text: Their journey towards what they hope will be a fifth victory

54.88.text: has seen them defeat Pembroke College, Cambridge,

57.68.text: by 220 points to 120 in the first round

60.80.text: and the Open University by 225 to 130 in the second.

65.12.text: With an accumulated score therefore of 445,

68.76.text: let's meet the Magdalen team for the third time.

73.64.text: I'm from Stone in Staffordshire, and I'm reading classics.

76.80.text: Hi, I'm Chris Savory from Burgess Hill in West Sussex

80.84.text:
- Their captain. 
- Hello, my name's Hugh Binnie.

82.80.text: I live near Cheltenham near Gloucestershire,

86.80.text: Hello, I'm Cameron J Quinn, originally

88.68.text: from Los Angeles, California, and I read philosophy and French.

95.92.text: Now teams from Trinity College, Cambridge,

98.36.text: have taken the series title on three occasions,

101.52.text: and they are, or course, the current reigning champions.

104.64.text: Their latest team has already dismissed

107.12.text: the University of St Andrews in round one with 150 points to 100

111.12.text: and Leicester University in round two by 220 to 140.

115.52.text: With an accumulated score, therefore, of 370,

118.92.text: let's meet the Trinity team for the third time.

122.04.text: Hi, I'm Matthew. I'm from London and I study physics.

125.16.text: Hello, I'm Claire. I'm from Greenwich in London and I study classics.

130.40.text: Hi, I'm Hugh. I'm from London and I'm studying chemistry.

133.72.text: Hi, I'm Aled. I'm from Birmingham and I'm studying maths.

142.88.text: OK, you all know the rules.

144.68.text: So fingers on the buzzers. Here's your first starter for ten.

147.92.text: The defeat of the Duke of Somerset at St Albans traditionally

151.64.text: marks the start of the first phase of which series of wars?

155.32.text: Later battles were at Northampton, Wakefield and St Albans again.

161.96.text:
- The Wars of the Roses. 
- Correct.

166.68.text: The first set of bonuses, Magdalen, are on trilogies.

170.76.text: Including The Soft Machine and The Ticket That Exploded,

174.60.text: The Nova Trilogy and The Cut-Up Trilogy are names sometimes given

178.56.text: to experimental works by which US author who died in 1997?

186.36.text:
- Asmuth's not American, is he? 
- Asmuth? No.

189.56.text:
- Erm... 
- DeLillo? Was he dead by then? 
- No, he's still alive, I think. 
- OK.

196.40.text:
- Bellow. 
- No, it's William S Burroughs.

199.48.text: The Van is the third novel in the Barrytown trilogy

202.72.text: by Roddy Doyle that began with which novel, published in 1987?

207.48.text: I think Paddy Clarke Ha Ha Ha is '93.

210.96.text: But if that's the only Roddy Doyle we have...

219.12.text: which US author wrote The Rosy Crucifixion trilogy,

222.84.text: whose three novels are Sexus, Plexus and Nexus?

236.32.text: No, it's Henry Miller. Ten points for this.

238.48.text: Who or what is the subject of the following lines

242.48.text:
- "I am the daughter of earth and water..." 
- BUZZER

246.84.text: Er, no, you lose five points.

250.12.text: "I pass through the pores of the ocean and shores,

257.20.text:
- Rain? 
- No, it's a cloud. Ten points for this.

260.56.text: "When his petulance and egotism are assessed,

265.92.text: "his real substance as the pre-eminent British proponent

269.40.text: "of democratic socialism in the 20th century outweighs everything."

273.60.text: These words refer to which former coal miner,

280.96.text:
- Er, Nye Bevan. 
- Nye Bevan, Aneurin Bevan.

283.24.text: I only say because sometimes people get him

288.76.text: Set of bonuses for you now, Magdalen. They're on the Caribbean.

292.40.text: Two main islands of which country in the Caribbean are separated

296.24.text: by a channel called The Narrows?

297.96.text: The smaller island has a name derived from the Spanish for snow.

301.56.text:
- What's the Spanish for snow? 
- Er, nieve.

305.16.text:
- St Kitts and Nevis. 
- Oh, yeah.

307.44.text:
- St Kitts and Nevis. 
- St Kitts and Nevis is right.

309.96.text: Which country in the Lesser Antilles consists of a major island

313.40.text: whose capital is Kingstown and an archipelago to the south

316.56.text: that contains the islands of Bequia and Mustique?

324.32.text:
- I don't know. Try it. 
- Grenada.

325.96.text: No, it's St Vincent and the Grenadines.

328.20.text: And finally, which country is named after two islands

331.12.text: whose respective capitals are Port-of-Spain and Scarborough?

335.16.text:
- Trinidad and Tobago. 
- Correct. Ten points for this. 
- APPLAUSE

338.72.text: In the Critias, what does Plato describe as

341.44.text: "greater in extent than Libya and Asia.

343.96.text:
- "When afterwards sunk by as earthquake, it became..." 
- BUZZER

352.72.text: These bonuses, Magdalen, are on natural history.

355.60.text: What two words are represented by the letters CC

358.96.text: in the abbreviation CCD coined in the 21st century?

363.08.text: The term describes a disorder that appears to have been documented

368.84.text: and was formerly known as Spring Dwindle or May Disease.

375.40.text:
- Any ideas at all? 
- No idea, sorry.

383.32.text: what substance is used to attach a honeycomb to the inside of a hive?

387.36.text: It's been valued as an antiseptic since ancient times

390.20.text: and was formerly used in wood varnishes.

392.72.text:
- I think it is beeswax. 
- Beeswax.

396.68.text: And finally, what term denotes male bees

399.04.text: that are expelled for the winter months when the hive

402.08.text: adopts a lean survival mode of existence?

409.84.text:
- Drones. 
- Correct. We're going to take a picture round.

414.48.text: you'll see a list of the dramatis personae of a 20th-century play.

418.00.text: For ten points, please give me the title of the play.

426.84.text: For you bonuses, you will now see the character lists

429.56.text: of three more notable 20th and 21st-century plays.

433.72.text: I want you to identify the play from its characters. Firstly.

446.24.text:
- It's not, like, The Ice Man Cometh? 
- Could it be The Ice Man Cometh?

452.40.text: No, that's Tennessee Williams' Cat On A Hot Tin Roof. And secondly.

464.60.text: Oh, erm, it's The History Boys.

466.36.text:
- The History Boys. 
- It is The History Boys by Alan Bennett.

469.24.text: Right, ten points for this starter question.

471.48.text: See if you can get off the mark with this, Trinity.

473.88.text: In a work of 1958, which economist used the expression

479.24.text: of a community where public services have failed to keep abreast

482.64.text: of private consumption, the work in question being The Affluent Society?

495.52.text: are on pairs of proper names that are eye rhymes.

498.24.text: That is, their spelling are similar,

500.44.text: but they do not rhyme, for example, James and Thames.

504.40.text: In each case, give both words from the explanations. Firstly,

508.20.text: the French artist whose works include The Dance Class

511.44.text: and Miss La La At The Cirque Fernando,

514.40.text: and the largest city of the state of Nevada.

522.12.text: Secondly, the author of The Razor's Edge and Of Human Bondage

528.36.text: who gives his name to a type of four-wheeled carriage.

533.56.text: Brougham? Is that how you say it? I don't know how you say it.

536.96.text: It's Maugham and...Brougham, just say that.

540.08.text:
- Maugham and Brougham. 
- I'll accept that.

545.00.text: But Maugham and Brougham is what I was looking for. You're right.

548.44.text: Finally, two poets, the authors of Ode To A Nightingale

553.52.text:
- Keats and Yeats. 
- Correct. Ten points for this.

558.72.text: Spain ceded which two territories to Britain?

562.16.text: One of them, the second-largest of the Balearic Islands,

565.24.text:
- was returned to Spain in 1802, but... 
- BUZZER

575.28.text: See if you can start the catch-up now with these bonuses on chemistry.

579.20.text: For what do the letters LFT stand

581.68.text: when describing a model developed to predict

584.32.text: all of the properties of transition metal complexes

587.20.text: when previous models were shown to be inadequate?

597.08.text: what is the term for a ligand with two lone pairs of electrons?

603.00.text: Many transition metal complexes are highly coloured

607.48.text: Name the metal and the ligand that compose Prussian blue.

611.60.text: Probably cobalt. Is it cobalt or something else?

615.12.text:
- Cobalt rings a bell. 
- With something else? 
- It could be cyanide.

623.04.text: No, it's cyanide and iron. Ten points for this.

627.52.text: which carboxylic acid is formed by hydration of fumaric acid

631.80.text: and, in the Krebs cycle, is oxidised to oxal-acetic acid?

642.84.text: These bonuses are on terms coined by social scientists.

646.20.text: What term did the US academic Irving Janis coin for the phenomenon

650.08.text: which can cause a group of people to make faulty decisions

653.12.text: when interpersonal pressures lead to a deterioration

655.96.text: of mental efficiency and moral judgment?

661.12.text: A term coined by the US sociologist Arlie Russell Hochschild

665.40.text: in her book The Managed Heart,

667.44.text: what type of labour is described as "the management of feeling to create

671.96.text: "a publicly observable facial and bodily display, sold for a wage"?

676.32.text:
- Do you know? 
- Something in the theatre. 
- Go for it.

682.28.text: Lastly, what two-word phrase did the British sociologist

685.44.text: Stanley Cohen coin when studying the public response

688.36.text: to mods and rockers in the 1960s?

690.20.text: It indicates a disproportionate public fear in response

693.36.text: to a perceived threat to social norms.

699.36.text:
- Moral panic. 
- Correct. Ten points for this.

702.44.text: Give the three letters of the alphabet

704.72.text: that appear together at the end of the surnames of the authors

708.08.text:
- of Zazie In The Metro, Reveries Of A Solitary Walker... 
- BUZZER

716.76.text: Right, you get a set of bonuses, Magdalen, on Hindu deities.

720.28.text: Also known by epithets meaning "great lord" and "beneficent",

723.68.text: the name of which god derives from the Sanskrit for "auspicious one"?

736.12.text: Shiva's vehicle in the world is Nandi,

738.84.text: who takes the form of what specific animal?

753.20.text:
- A snake. 
- No, it's a bull.

755.12.text: According to one version of the myth,

757.16.text: which god was created by Parvati and beheaded by Shiva,

760.32.text: who later replaced the missing head with that of an elephant?

765.56.text: We're going to take a music round now. For you music starter,

768.52.text: you'll hear a piece of 20th-century orchestral music.

771.28.text: Ten points if you can give me its title, please.

784.48.text: An American In Paris also appears in Of Thee I Sing,

790.20.text: and the first musical to win the Pulitzer prize for drama.

793.36.text: For your bonuses, three more US musicals that have won that prize.

796.76.text: In each case, I simply want the title of the musical.

808.24.text: Secondly, a winner in 1962 which was revived in 2011.

814.88.text: # How to apply for a job... #

817.20.text:
- A Chorus Line.

819.04.text: # How to advance from the mail room... #

828.60.text: # There is nothing like a dame... #

835.28.text:
- Guys And Dolls.

- Murakami.

906.12.text:
- and Samson are figures who appear in which book of the Old...?

916.12.text: Your bonuses this time, Magdalen, are on botany.

923.36.text: for the hook formed by the terminal cells of asco-genous hyphae?

929.44.text: Is it looking like a scroll?

936.44.text:
- What did you say it was, sorry? 
- A scroll? 
- A scroll?

939.88.text:
- A scroll.

942.80.text: A crosier is formed by the young circinate fronds

945.88.text: of which group of non-flowering plants as they emerge from the soil?

951.08.text:
- Ferns.

954.20.text: Finally, the frond of a fern is diploid.

958.80.text: what is this diploid stage called?

960.92.text: The term in question means "spore producing."

983.92.text:
- It's major ethnic groups include the Hausa, Yoruba...

998.64.text: with a grouping of back-bench conservative MPS established

1001.68.text: by Lord Randolph Churchill at London's Carlton Club in 1883?

1008.60.text:
- Don't know. Rose? I don't know.

1011.92.text: No, it's the primrose. Primrose League.

1018.84.text: was Archibald John Primrose more commonly known?

1025.64.text:
- Earl of Rosebury.

1043.32.text:
- What was the day?

- No, no the flower?

1049.56.text: No, it's Disraeli. Ten points for this.

1052.36.text: Goliath, Freud, Fifi, Frodo, Spring Goblin and David Greybeard

1057.28.text:
- were among the chimpanzees named and studied by which British...?

1061.68.text:
- Goodall.

1071.44.text: a French hydraulic engineer born in 1695,

1074.36.text: which piece of apparatus measures flow velocity

1082.08.text:
- No?

1097.72.text: Is it, like, the level thing?

1113.60.text: that can be made by reacting a liquid with a solid?

1118.84.text: You are a chemist. You should know. LAUGHTER

1140.76.text:
- Rubens. 
- It is Rubens, yes.

1145.84.text: That is part of a collection in Munich.

1148.28.text: For your bonuses, you will now see three garden scenes

1152.68.text: In each case, I simply want the name of the artist.

1158.32.text:
- It'll be Klee. 
- Yeah, it does look like... Yeah.

1162.32.text: Yes, it's usually pronounced "clay." It's Bird Garden.

1174.64.text:
- Nothing. I don't know. 
- Do we have anything else to offer? 
- No.

1179.56.text:
- It is indeed. 
- Oh! 
- Yes, it's the Garden Terrace.

1193.92.text: Do we want to go with Klimt, you may.

1196.96.text:
- Klimt. 
- It is Klimt. Farm Garden With Flowers.

1203.32.text: Right, ten points at stake for this.

1205.32.text: Fingers on the buzzers, answer as soon as your name is called.

1208.36.text: How many years separate the execution of King Charles I

1212.04.text:
- and the restoration of King Charles...?

1215.28.text:
- 12. 
- No, and I'm afraid you must lose five points for that as well.

1219.52.text: The Restoration of King Charles II?

1221.96.text:
- Anyone like to buzz from Magdalen? 
- BUZZER

1226.56.text: 11 is correct. Yes, it's just under 11 years, four months.

1230.08.text: Right, you get a set of bonuses now on US secretaries of State.

1236.36.text: to the Cuban missile crisis, but was vilified by many

1239.96.text: for his support of American involvement in Vietnam?

1242.92.text:
- It's not, is it? 
- McNamara? 
- Yeah.

1245.32.text:
- McNamara.

1252.20.text: He went on to help reach agreement with the Soviet Union

1268.52.text:
- Rumsfeld.

1270.44.text: And finally, Warren Christopher and Madeleine Albright

1276.04.text:
- Clinton. 
- Correct. Ten points for this.

1283.04.text: is a public service television broadcaster

1293.20.text: These bonuses, Magdalen College, are on films.

1296.04.text: Firstly, based on the life of a Nobel laureate in economics,

- A Beautiful Mind.

1310.88.text: writing under the pen-name FX Toole?

- I thought Crash was 2004.

1328.20.text: And finally, which 2005 film is an adaptation of a short story

1334.68.text:
- Brokeback Mountain.

1337.36.text: What ascending sequence of numbers links Bruckner's Romantic symphony,

1351.32.text: These bonuses are on regions of Italy, Trinity College.

1369.00.text:

1392.68.text:
- San Marino... I think the Venetos are round San Marino.

1405.16.text:
- Lazio. 
- Correct. Ten points for this.

1410.72.text: are inscribed on the sarcophagus of which medieval

1413.80.text: Franciscan philosopher, known as Doctor Subtilis?

1423.00.text: These bonuses, Magdalen College, are on a title.

1425.92.text: Edward III of England publicly claimed which title

1433.00.text: Who, by the age of ten, had in separate ceremonies been crowned

1436.08.text: both King of England and of France?

1438.12.text: He lost both titles, along with his life, 40 years later.

1454.88.text:
- George II. 
- No, it was George III.

1457.20.text: There's about three and a quarter minutes to go

1460.84.text: The Human Condition, The Pleasure Principle

1463.56.text:
- and The Treachery Of Images are paintings by which...? 
- BUZZER

1472.00.text: Your bonuses this time are on former military ranks.

1474.32.text: Now replaced by second lieutenant in the British Army,

1478.44.text: held by commissioned officers in the US Navy?

1485.24.text: Their responsibilities included carrying regimental colours.

1488.60.text:
- Cornet. 
- Correct. Which current rank in the British Army

1494.76.text: I'd hazard a guess at lieutenant-colonel.

1498.44.text:
- Lieutenant-Colonel. 
- No, it's brigadier. Ten points for this.

1501.84.text: Who was the leader of the expedition recounted

1504.92.text: in Apsley Cherry-Garrad's 1922 work The Worst Journey In The World?

1521.84.text: In each case, name the country

1523.40.text: in which the following major cities are located.

1535.16.text: Secondly, Merida, San Cristobal and Maracaibo.

1552.72.text: And finally, Fortaleza, Porto Alegre and Salvador.

1557.00.text:
- That's Chile? 
- I'm not sure. Salvador...

1560.84.text:
- Could be Brazil. 
- Go for Brazil then.

1564.32.text:
- Brazil. 
- Correct. Ten points for this.

1567.32.text: "In the spring, a young man's fancy lightly turns

1570.00.text: "to thoughts of love." Which poet wrote this

1584.04.text: Your bonuses are on politics in the 1830s.

1586.68.text: In 1834, William IV became the last British monarch to dismiss

1590.40.text: a Prime Minister who still had the confidence of the House of Commons.

1599.68.text:
- It was later. 
- Well, Melbourne would be my guess, I just don't know.

1604.76.text: The king's decision was based on Melbourne's appointment

1607.80.text: of which reforming Whig as chancellor?

1610.64.text: He was later Prime Minister from 1846 to '52 and from 1865 to '66.

1619.80.text:
- Palmerstone. 
- No, it was Lord John Russell.

1622.16.text: The Duke of Wellington served briefly

1624.20.text: as "caretaker" Prime Minister before which Tory took over?

1627.44.text: Serving for less than one year, he became Prime Minister again in 1841.

1639.84.text:
- Palmerstone. 
- No, it's Sir Robert Peel. Ten points for this.

1643.28.text:
- Up, down, top, bottom, strange and charm...? 
- BUZZER

1646.72.text:
- Quark. 
- Quarks is correct. Here are your bonuses.

1652.80.text: In each case, give the English translation of the Latin name

1656.00.text: of a feature on the Moon's surface.

1660.80.text:
- Sea of sleep? 
- Sea of sleep.

1670.20.text:
- Black? No, cloud. 
- Sea of clouds.

1679.96.text: Bend of colours. I don't know.

1681.88.text:
- Bend of colours. 
- It's bay of rainbows. 
- GONG

1684.92.text: And at the gong, Trinity College, Cambridge, have 55.

1693.40.text: You were on nothing like as good form today

1695.76.text: as you were last time we saw you, Trinity.

1697.80.text: But never mind - you've got a chance to live again.

1700.00.text: So we shall look forward to seeing you in your second quarterfinal.

1705.36.text: and we shall look forward to seeing you again.

1707.32.text: You only have to win one more match

1708.84.text: to go straight through to the semifinals,

1710.76.text: as opposed to the two that Trinity now have to win.

1714.88.text: I hope you can join us next time for another quarterfinal match,

1717.60.text:
- but until then, it's goodbye from Trinity College, Cambridge. 
- Goodbye.

1720.92.text:
- It's goodbye from Magdalen College, Oxford. 
- Goodbye.

1723.36.text: And it's goodbye from me, goodbye.
